subsection_name: viem-duong-ruot.json_4_How to treat inflammatory bowel disease
subsection_content:
Depending on the severity of intestinal inflammation, your doctor will prescribe appropriate treatment:
1. Treatment with medication
For most cases of inflammatory bowel disease, doctors will prescribe the following medications:
Anti-inflammatory drugs: Aminosalicylate anti-inflammatory drugs such as mesalamine, balsalazide, and olsalazine are often the first solution in treating mild to moderate ulcerative colitis. Corticosteroids for short-term use: Main effects are to reduce inflammation and suppress immunity.; Anti-inflammatory drugs: Aminosalicylate anti-inflammatory drugs such as mesalamine, balsalazide, and olsalazine are often the first solution in treating mild to moderate ulcerative colitis. Corticosteroids for short-term use: Main effects are to reduce inflammation and suppress immunity.; Aminosalicylate anti-inflammatory drugs such as mesalamine, balsalazide, and olsalazine are often the first line of treatment for mild to moderate ulcerative colitis.; Corticosteroids for short-term use: Main effects are to reduce inflammation and suppress immunity.
Immunosuppressants: These drugs work by blocking the immune response that releases inflammatory chemicals in the body, thereby avoiding damage to the intestinal lining. Some commonly prescribed types include: azathioprine, mercaptopurine, methotrexate.; Immunosuppressants: These drugs work by blocking the immune response that releases inflammatory chemicals in the body, thereby avoiding damage to the intestinal lining. Some commonly prescribed types include: azathioprine, mercaptopurine, methotrexate.
Biological drugs: Biological drugs are a new group of drugs used to inhibit proteins that cause inflammatory reactions in the body. Some commonly used drugs are infliximab, adalimumab, certolizumab, vedolizumab, ustekinumab.; Biological drugs: Biological drugs are a new group of drugs used to inhibit proteins that cause inflammatory reactions in the body. Some commonly used drugs are infliximab, adalimumab, certolizumab, vedolizumab, ustekinumab.
Antibiotics: Antibiotics are often used when an infection is suspected, as in the case of perianal Crohn's disease; Antibiotics: Antibiotics are often used when an infection is suspected, as in the case of perianal Crohn's disease.
Anti-diarrheal medications: Fiber supplements such as psyllium powder, methylcellulose. Loperamide is used in cases of severe diarrhea.; Anti-diarrheal medications: Fiber supplements such as psyllium powder, methylcellulose. Loperamide is used in cases of severe diarrhea.
Pain reliever: Acetaminophen for mild pain. Non-steroidal pain relievers such as ibuprofen, naproxen, diclofenac... can make the disease worse and should be avoided.; Pain reliever: Acetaminophen for mild pain. Non-steroidal pain relievers such as ibuprofen, naproxen, diclofenac... can make the disease worse and should be avoided.
People with inflammatory bowel disease must consult their doctor before using the drug. Some immunosuppressant drugs can increase the risk of serious infections. Therefore, patients should take screening tests for tuberculosis, hepatitis B, C... and receive all recommended vaccines before starting treatment with drugs that have the ability to suppress the immune system.
2. Surgery
For serious cases that cannot be effectively treated with medication, your doctor may recommend surgery, specifically as follows:
Ulcerative colitis surgery (removal of the entire colon and rectum).; Removing a damaged part of the digestive tract and joining the healthy parts back together.
